Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A client has sent a standard contract for a routine service engagement that is not due back for quite some time.
Story: I was just settling in at my desk, ready to review a client’s service contract, when my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his name flashing with a desperate “Can you call me? Furniture emergency!” I glanced at the contract on my screen. It wasn’t urgent—plenty of time before the deadline—but I’d promised myself I’d get ahead on work today. Still, I could picture Sam surrounded by a jumble of boards and screws, frustration mounting. He’d helped me move last year, no questions asked. As a friend, I wanted to be there for him, to offer the quick support he needed. But as a lawyer, I felt the weight of my professional standards, the need to stay disciplined and focused, to not let personal matters chip away at my work ethic. My finger hovered over the call button, my mind tugged in two directions—toward loyalty and laughter, or toward diligence and duty. The pressure built in my chest as I tried to decide which role to honor first.
